fields.name: Adaptive teaching > What a newly qualified teacher (NQT) needs to learn

fields.title: Plan and teach well structured lessons

fields.text: Demonstrate good subject and curriculum knowledge

fields.title: Supporting early career teachers > Promote good progress

content.value: Promote good progress
Giving struggling pupils special attention
Where pupils are struggling, NQTs should be responsive and adapt lessons so they provide targeted support for those who need extra help to succeed.

fields.title: Using technology to aid school improvement

content.value: Using technology to aid school improvement
Appreciating the differences between pupils

Some pupils will have prior knowledge of subjects, others will have barriers that need to be overcome before they can learn. NQTs should take differences between pupils into account when preparing lessons.
Planning lessons without worrying about learning styles

There's no evidence to suggest that pupils have different learning styles. NQTs should focus on developing lessons that address the needs of pupils, rather than trying to tailor them to different styles of learning.

fields.title: Making effective use of teaching assistants
Adaptive teaching > What a newly qualified teacher (NQT) needs to learn

content.value: What a newly qualified teacher (NQT) needs to learn
There are 7 areas an NQT needs to understand and gain experience in.
Focusing on pupils with special needs
Pupils with special educational needs or disabilities may require more support. NQTs should work closely with colleagues, families and pupils to understand and tackle any barriers to learning.

fields.text: Plan and teach well structured lessons

content.value: Understanding how pupils learn at different speeds
Pupils learn at different rates. Recognising the varying speeds at which pupils learn, and the different types of help they need, will help NQTs create a supportive learning environment.
Resources

fields.title: Adaptive teaching > What skills an NQT needs to develop

content.value: What skills an NQT needs to develop
To help NQTs succeed, mentors should dedicate time to sharing their experience of:
identifying pupils who need extra help
adapting lessons to support pupils with different needs
developing lessons that create a positive learning environment for the whole class
A mentor needs to help NQTs know how to:
understand the needs of different pupils
allow all pupils to experience success
support individual needs without creating unnecessary work
put pupils into flexible groups to aid learning
Understanding different pupil needs
An NQT needs to be able to:
spot pupils who would benefit from breaking down lessons into smaller chunks that are easier to understand
use formative assessment to help NQTs modify their teaching and help improve learning
work with special education and safeguarding leads to work out which pupils need attention
use the SEND code of practice for guidance when deciding which pupils would benefit from additional support
The importance of experiencing success
An NQT needs to be able to:
adapt lessons so that all pupils have a chance to experience success while maintaining high expectations
slowly introduce new content in lessons, so that all pupils have a chance to understand important concepts
Meeting individual needs without unnecessary workload
An NQT needs to be able to:
make best use of all resources available to them, including textbooks
address knowledge gaps first to connect with pupils' existing knowledge if pupils lack critical knowledge before NQTs introduce new content
frame questions in such a way that pupils understand the question and can draw on their existing knowledge
consider if it's more efficient to work with struggling pupils in small groups as part of lessons, or to arrange special lessons for these pupils another time
Grouping pupils
An NQT needs to be able to:
have high expectations for all groups of pupils and offer a rich curriculum
change groups regularly so that pupils don't think these groups are fixed
ensure groups are subject specific when they are based on attainment

fields.title: Supporting early career teachers > Adaptive teaching

content.value: Adaptive teaching
Creating and monitoring learning groups

NQTs should organise pupils into flexible groups to give support to those who need it most. Closely monitoring these groups will allow NQTs to spot any impacts on engagement or motivation, and swop groups around if necessary.

fields.title: Supporting early career teachers > Manage behaviour effectively

content.value: Manage behaviour effectively

fields.title: Make accurate and productive use of assessment
Supporting early career teachers > Plan and teach well structured lessons

content.value: Plan and teach well structured lessons
Treating groups of pupils the same

If groups of pupils are given different tasks to complete, it can lower expectations for some students. NQTs should give all pupils the same tasks, and give extra support to any groups of students who are struggling.
